item.title: Tour de France 2015: stage ten
item.trailText: All the best images from stage ten, a 167 km mountain stage between Tarbes and La Pierre-Saint-Martin
item.standFirst: All the best images from stage ten, a 167 km trip between Tarbes and La Pierre-Saint-Martin. It’s the first mountain stage of this year’s tour, finishing with a punishing climb up the Col de Soudet to La Pierre-Saint-Martin in the Pyrenees

displayImages.caption: Reinardt Janse van Rensburg of the MTN-Qhubeka team visits the barber before the start of the stage  Photograph: Bryn Lennon/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Reinardt Janse van Rensburg of the MTN-Qhubeka team visits the barber shop before the start of the stage
displayImages.cleanCaption: Reinardt Janse van Rensburg of the MTN-Qhubeka team visits the barber before the start of the stage

displayImages.caption: That helmet’s not going to offer him much protection is he comes off his bike... Photograph: Stefano Rellandini/Reuters
displayImages.altText: That helmet’s not going to offer him much protection is he comes off his bike
displayImages.cleanCaption: That helmet’s not going to offer him much protection is he comes off his bike...

displayImages.caption: Riders wait for the start of the stage on a sunny day in Tarbes. Photograph: Christophe Ena/AP
displayImages.altText: Riders wait for the start of the stage
displayImages.cleanCaption: Riders wait for the start of the stage on a sunny day in Tarbes.

displayImages.caption: Photographers are reflected in the glasses of Eritrea’s Daniel Teklehaimanot, wearing the best climber’s polka-dot jersey, as he waits for race to get underway Photograph: Jeff Pachoud/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Photographers are reflected in glasses of Eritrea’s Daniel Teklehaimanot, wearing the best climber’s polka dot jersey, as he waits for race to get underway
displayImages.cleanCaption: Photographers are reflected in the glasses of Eritrea’s Daniel Teklehaimanot, wearing the best climber’s polka-dot jersey, as he waits for race to get underway

displayImages.caption: The peloton makes its way along the flatter early stages of the route... Photograph: Lionel Bonaventure/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The pack rides
displayImages.cleanCaption: The peloton makes its way along the flatter early stages of the route...

displayImages.caption: ...which passes through the French countryside on its way to the Pyrenees. Photograph: Bryn Lennon/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: And snakes through the French countryside
displayImages.cleanCaption: ...which passes through the French countryside on its way to the Pyrenees.

displayImages.caption: As it’s Bastille Day, it’s no surprise to as see a host of Tricolores along the route  Photograph: Eric Gaillard/Reuters
displayImages.altText: As it’s Bastille Day, it’s no surprise to as see a host of Tricolores along the route
displayImages.cleanCaption: As it’s Bastille Day, it’s no surprise to as see a host of Tricolores along the route

displayImages.caption: The peloton passes a field of sunflowers to create a classic Tour de France image Photograph: Yoan Valat/EPA
displayImages.altText: There’s also plenty of sunflowers
displayImages.cleanCaption: The peloton passes a field of sunflowers to create a classic Tour de France image

displayImages.caption: Horses race alongside the peloton, which passed through the Hautes–Pyrénées and Pyrénées-Atlantiques départements in south-west France Photograph: Yoan Valat/EPA
displayImages.altText: As well as some equine company for the riders
displayImages.cleanCaption: Horses race alongside the peloton, which passed through the Hautes–Pyrénées and Pyrénées-Atlantiques départements in south-west France

displayImages.caption: Local bovines seem more interested in the cameras than the riders behind them Photograph: Jeff Pachoud/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: And some bovine companytoo , though they don’t seem very interested in the race
displayImages.cleanCaption: Local bovines seem more interested in the cameras than the riders behind them

displayImages.caption: A different kind of cycling, as a BMX rider throws shapes with race leader Chris Froome visible in the background Photograph: Laurent Cipriani/AP
displayImages.altText: Man performs a BMX stunt
displayImages.cleanCaption: A different kind of cycling, as a BMX rider throws shapes with race leader Chris Froome visible in the background

displayImages.caption: Riders are reflected in a window as they pass through a town Photograph: Christophe Ena/AP
displayImages.altText: Riders are reflected in a window as they pass through a town
displayImages.cleanCaption: Riders are reflected in a window as they pass through a town

displayImages.caption: Firefighters spray water across the road to welcome the peloton Photograph: Lionel Bonaventure/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Firefighters spray water to welcome the peloton
displayImages.cleanCaption: Firefighters spray water across the road to welcome the peloton

displayImages.caption: Team Giant–Alpecin’s Warren Barguil looks to be in a pain after a crash in a feeding zone Photograph: Christophe Ena/AP
displayImages.altText: Warren Barguil looks to be in a bit of pain after crashing in a feeding zone
displayImages.cleanCaption: Team Giant–Alpecin’s Warren Barguil looks to be in a pain after a crash in a feeding zone

displayImages.caption: Fans gather at the finish line at the ski resort of La Pierre-Saint-Martin, at the top of the Col de Soudet Photograph: Stefano Rellandini/REUTERS
displayImages.altText: La Pierre Saint Martin
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fans gather at the finish line at the ski resort of La Pierre-Saint-Martin, at the top of the Col de Soudet

displayImages.caption: Breakaway rider Pierrick Fedrigo is given encouragement by a glamorous spectator as the pack closes in Photograph: Lionel Bonaventure/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Fedrigo
displayImages.cleanCaption: Breakaway rider Pierrick Fedrigo is given encouragement by a glamorous spectator as the pack closes in

displayImages.caption: The pack of riders arrive at the foot of the hors categorie Col de Soudet Photograph: Eric Gaillard/Reuters
displayImages.altText: The pack of riders deal with an incline
displayImages.cleanCaption: The pack of riders arrive at the foot of the hors categorie Col de Soudet

displayImages.caption: Chris Froome, wearing the overall leader’s yellow jersey, BMC’s Tejay van Garderen, and Nairo Quintana, wearing the best young rider’s white jersey, make their way up the climb Photograph: Lionel Bonaventure/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Chris Froome, wearing the overall leader’s yellow jersey, Tejay Van Garderen, and Nairo Quintana, wearing the best young’s white jersey, make their way up an incline
displayImages.cleanCaption: Chris Froome, wearing the overall leader’s yellow jersey, BMC’s Tejay van Garderen, and Nairo Quintana, wearing the best young rider’s white jersey, make their way up the climb

displayImages.caption: Fans at the top of the mountain enjoy the view across the Pyrenees Photograph: Bryn Lennon/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: What a view
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fans at the top of the mountain enjoy the view across the Pyrenees

displayImages.caption: Nairo Quintana climbs towards the finish line. Quintana, a pre-Tour favourite, ended the day in third in the general classification Photograph: Laurent Cipriani/AP
displayImages.altText: Quintana
displayImages.cleanCaption: Nairo Quintana climbs towards the finish line. Quintana, a pre-Tour favourite, ended the day in third in the general classification

displayImages.caption: Spectators see the peloton approach on a sunny day in the mountains Photograph: Benoit Tessier/REUTERS
displayImages.altText: Watching the riders
displayImages.cleanCaption: Spectators see the peloton approach on a sunny day in the mountains

displayImages.caption: Alberto Contador goes for one final push on the last climb, but the former champion is now four minutes behind race leader Froome Photograph: Lionel Bonaventure/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Alberto Contador goes for one final push on the last hill
displayImages.cleanCaption: Alberto Contador goes for one final push on the last climb, but the former champion is now four minutes behind race leader Froome

displayImages.caption: Chris Froome tells fans to move out of the way as he races up the Col de Soudet Photograph: Bryn Lennon/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Though he has no chance of catching Chris Froome, who is a good two minutes ahead of him. The yellow jersey holder has to signal to fans to move out of the way as he climbs Col de Soudet
displayImages.cleanCaption: Chris Froome tells fans to move out of the way as he races up the Col de Soudet

displayImages.caption: Froome finished over a minute clear of his GC rivals, extending his overall lead to 2 minutes, 52 seconds Photograph: Lionel Bonaventure/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Here’s a rider’s eye view of Froome navigating through the crowd
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froome finished over a minute clear of his GC rivals, extending his overall lead to 2 minutes, 52 seconds

displayImages.caption: Froome crosses the line after a breathtaking climb to take control of the race for the yellow jersey Photograph: Doug Pensinger/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Froome manages to get through the crowd unscathed and approaches the finish line
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froome crosses the line after a breathtaking climb to take control of the race for the yellow jersey

displayImages.caption: Froome looks delighted after a stupendous performance leaves him almost three minutes clear of his rivals Photograph: Peter Dejong/AP
displayImages.altText: He’s got every reason to look that happy as he crosses the line, it was a stupendous performance by the Team Sky rider
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froome looks delighted after a stupendous performance leaves him almost three minutes clear of his rivals

displayImages.caption: Froome not only retains the yellow jersey, with van Garderen second, but he also takes the best climber’s polka-dot jersey Photograph: Yoan Valat/EPA
displayImages.altText: Froome on the podium wearing the best climber’s polka-dot jersey
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froome not only retains the yellow jersey, with van Garderen second, but he also takes the best climber’s polka-dot jersey

image.caption: Reinardt Janse van Rensburg of the MTN-Qhubeka team visits the barber before the start of the stage  Photograph: Bryn Lennon/Getty Images

cards.title: In pictures / Froch's career path from an amateur to a world champion
cards.rawTitle: Froch's career path from an amateur to a world champion

item.title: Carl Froch's career
item.trailText: As Carl Froch announces that he’s hanging up his gloves, we take a look back at the four-time world super middleweight champion’s time in the ring
item.standFirst: As Carl Froch announces that he’s hanging up his gloves, we take a look back at the four-time world super middleweight champion’s time in the ring

displayImages.caption: Carl Froch won the WBC, WBA and IBF super-middleweight titles during a highly successful career Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Carl Froch
displayImages.cleanCaption: Carl Froch won the WBC, WBA and IBF super-middleweight titles during a highly successful career
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Froch, second left, pictured in August 2000 with Audley Harrison, left, and Courtney Fry, second right who both represented Team GB at the Sydney Olympics the following month. Froch missed out on qualifying for the Games, losing on points in a final eliminator Photograph: Christopher Lee/Action Images
displayImages.altText: Froch, second left, pictured in August 2000 with Audley Harrison, left, and Courtney Fry, second right who both represented Team GB at the Sydney Olympics the following month. Froch missed out on qualifying for the Games, losing on points in a final eliminator
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froch, second left, pictured in August 2000 with Audley Harrison, left, and Courtney Fry, second right who both represented Team GB at the Sydney Olympics the following month. Froch missed out on qualifying for the Games, losing on points in a final eliminator

displayImages.caption: Dean Frost throws a body punch at Froch during their bout at the ABA National Championships in 2001 Photograph: Jason O'Brien/Action Images
displayImages.altText: Dean Frost throws a body punch at Froch during their bout at the ABA National Championships in 2001
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dean Frost throws a body punch at Froch during their bout at the ABA National Championships in 2001

displayImages.caption: Froch sizes up Michael Duffield during their super-middleweight contest at the Goresbrook Leisure Centre in Dagenham Photograph: Robert Hallam/Rex Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: Froch sizes up Michael Duffield during their super-middleweight contest at the Goresbrook Leisure Centre in Dagenham
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froch sizes up Michael Duffield during their super-middleweight contest at the Goresbrook Leisure Centre in Dagenham

displayImages.caption: Froch celebrates after his first round knockout of Damon Hague gave him the vacant British super middleweight title Photograph: Michael Regan/Action Images
displayImages.altText: Froch celebrates after his first round knockout of Damon Hague gave him the vacant British super middleweight title
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froch celebrates after his first round knockout of Damon Hague gave him the vacant British super middleweight title

displayImages.caption: Froch “floors” Nottingham Forest footballer Nathan Tyson during publicity ahead of his fight against Tony Dobson Photograph: Paul Childs/Action Images
displayImages.altText: Froch “floors” Nottingham Forest footballer Nathan Tyson during publicity ahead of his fight against Tony Dobson
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froch “floors” Nottingham Forest footballer Nathan Tyson during publicity ahead of his fight against Tony Dobson

displayImages.caption: Jean Pascal evades a big right from Froch during their fight for the vacant WBC super middleweight title, which Froch won with a unanimous decision in 2008 Photograph: Paul Childs/Action Images
displayImages.altText: Jean Pascal evades a big right from Froch during their fight for the vacant WBC super middleweight title, which Froch won with a unanimous decision in 2008
displayImages.cleanCaption: Jean Pascal evades a big right from Froch during their fight for the vacant WBC super middleweight title, which Froch won with a unanimous decision in 2008

displayImages.caption: Four months later Froch retained the title with a TKO in the final round when he took on Jermain Taylor Photograph: PA
displayImages.altText: Four months later Froch retained the title with a TKO in the final round when he took on Jermain Taylor
displayImages.cleanCaption: Four months later Froch retained the title with a TKO in the final round when he took on Jermain Taylor

displayImages.caption: In April 2010 Froch was defending his WBC super middleweight Title against Mikkel Kessler Photograph: Nick Potts/PA
displayImages.altText: In April 2010 Froch was defending his WBC super middleweight Title against Mikkel Kessler
displayImages.cleanCaption: In April 2010 Froch was defending his WBC super middleweight Title against Mikkel Kessler

displayImages.caption: After 26 straight wins Froch tasted defeat for the first time as a professional fighter when Kessler took the title with a unanimous decision  Photograph: Simon Dawson/AP
displayImages.altText: After 26 straight wins Froch tasted defeat for the first time as a professional fighter when Kessler took the title with a unanimous decision
displayImages.cleanCaption: After 26 straight wins Froch tasted defeat for the first time as a professional fighter when Kessler took the title with a unanimous decision

displayImages.caption: Arthur Abraham takes a big body hit as as he and Froch battle for the vacant WBC super middleweight title Photograph: Martin Rose/Bongarts/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Arthur Abraham takes a big body hit as as he and Froch battle for the vacant WBC super middleweight title
displayImages.cleanCaption: Arthur Abraham takes a big body hit as as he and Froch battle for the vacant WBC super middleweight title

displayImages.caption: Froch won with a unanimous decision and he celebrates the win with girlfriend Rachael Cordingley Photograph: Andrew Couldridge/Action Images
displayImages.altText: Froch won with a unanimous decision and he celebrates the win with girlfriend Rachael Cordingley
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froch won with a unanimous decision and he celebrates the win with girlfriend Rachael Cordingley

displayImages.caption: December 2011 saw Froch fighting in the United States for the second time of his career Photograph: Andrew Couldridge/Action Images
displayImages.altText: December 2011 saw Froch fighting in the United States for the second time of his career
displayImages.cleanCaption: December 2011 saw Froch fighting in the United States for the second time of his career

displayImages.caption: And for the second time in his career he tasted defeat when Andre Ward won by a unanimous decision to take the WBA/WBC super middleweight titles Photograph: Nick Laham/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: And for the second time in his career he tasted defeat when Andre Ward won by a unanimous decision to take the WBA/WBC super middleweight titles
displayImages.cleanCaption: And for the second time in his career he tasted defeat when Andre Ward won by a unanimous decision to take the WBA/WBC super middleweight titles

displayImages.caption: May 2013 gave Froch a chance to revenge the first defeat of his career when he took on Kessler in London Photograph: Scott Heavey/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: May 2013 gave Froch a chance to revenge the first defeat of his career when he took on Kessler in London
displayImages.cleanCaption: May 2013 gave Froch a chance to revenge the first defeat of his career when he took on Kessler in London

displayImages.caption: Like their first meeting, the fight went the distance only this time the result was different with Froch winning by a unanimous decision Photograph: Scott Heavey/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Like their first meeting, the fight went the distance only this time the result was different with Froch winning by a unanimous decision
displayImages.cleanCaption: Like their first meeting, the fight went the distance only this time the result was different with Froch winning by a unanimous decision

displayImages.caption: The IBF installed George Groves as Froch’s mandatory challenger and they fought in Manchester in November 2013 Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: The IBF installed George Groves as Froch’s mandatory challenger and they fought in Manchester in November 2013
displayImages.cleanCaption: The IBF installed George Groves as Froch’s mandatory challenger and they fought in Manchester in November 2013
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Froch came back and landed some powerful blows in the 9th round Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Froch came back and landed some powerful blows in the 9th round
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froch came back and landed some powerful blows in the 9th round
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: After which the referee Howard Foster stepped in to stop the fight. This was controversial as many observers felt that he had stepped in prematurely. The three judges had scored Groves ahead before Froch’s final onslaught and the controversial ending prompted a widespread demand for a rematch Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: After which the referee Howard Foster stepped in to stop the fight. This was controversial as many observers felt that he had stepped in prematurely. The three judges had scored Groves ahead before Froch’s final onslaught and the controversial ending prompted a widespread demand for a rematch
displayImages.cleanCaption: After which the referee Howard Foster stepped in to stop the fight. This was controversial as many observers felt that he had stepped in prematurely. The three judges had scored Groves ahead before Froch’s final onslaught and the controversial ending prompted a widespread demand for a rematch
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: In February 2014 Eddie Hearn and Matchroom Boxing announced that Froch v Groves II would take place on 31 May 2014 at Wembley Stadium Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: In February 2014 Eddie Hearn and Matchroom Boxing announced that Froch v Groves II would take place on 31 May 2014 at Wembley Stadium
displayImages.cleanCaption: In February 2014 Eddie Hearn and Matchroom Boxing announced that Froch v Groves II would take place on 31 May 2014 at Wembley Stadium
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: The fight was a significantly more cagey affair than the first match, with both fighters initially looking to outbox each other Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: The fight was a significantly more cagey affair than the first match, with both fighters initially looking to outbox each other
displayImages.cleanCaption: The fight was a significantly more cagey affair than the first match, with both fighters initially looking to outbox each other
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Froch was stronger in the first half of the fight Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Froch was stronger in the first half of the fight
displayImages.cleanCaption: Froch was stronger in the first half of the fight
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Groves came out fighting in the 8th round Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Groves came out fighting in the 8th round
displayImages.cleanCaption: Groves came out fighting in the 8th round
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: But then Froch got Groves pinned against the ropes and delivered a stunning, sensational right hand which knocked the challenger out Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: But then Froch got Groves pinned against the ropes and delivered a stunning, sensational right hand which knocked the challenger out
displayImages.cleanCaption: But then Froch got Groves pinned against the ropes and delivered a stunning, sensational right hand which knocked the challenger out
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Carl Froch celebrates with his WBA/IBF super middleweight title belts after his victory  Photograph: Andrew Couldridge/Action Images
displayImages.altText: Carl Froch celebrates with his WBA/IBF super middleweight title belts after his victory
displayImages.cleanCaption: Carl Froch celebrates with his WBA/IBF super middleweight title belts after his victory

displayImages.caption: He then celebrated the win by proposing to his girlfriend Photograph: Andrew Couldridge/Action Images
displayImages.altText: He then celebrated the win by proposing to his girlfriend

image.caption: After which the referee Howard Foster stepped in to stop the fight. This was controversial as many observers felt that he had stepped in prematurely. cards.title: Loop the loop / BMX rider lands the first quadruple backflip
cards.rawTitle: BMX rider lands the first quadruple backflip

item.title: BMX rider lands first ever quadruple backflip
item.trailText: Jed Mildon successfully pulls off the first ever BMX quadruple backflip
item.standFirst:
Jed Mildon successfully pulls off the first BMX quadruple backflip. Both Mildon and fellow rider James Foster have been attempting to land the trick, with the latter having broken ribs and even separated a shoulder in his efforts. But New Zealander Mildon has now flawlessly executed the trick. In 2011, Mildon was the first in BMX history to perform a triple backflip

• Watch the full video

cards.title: Golf / Woods confident before tackling the Open
cards.rawTitle: Woods confident before tackling the Open

item.title: Tiger Woods feeling confident ahead of St Andrews
item.trailText: Tiger Woods insists he is not 'buried and done', after recovering from back surgery ahead of this week's Open
item.standFirst: Tiger Woods insists he is not 'buried and done' after recovering from back surgery ahead of this week's Open. Woods, winner of 14 majors, says he still has his eyes on Jack Nicklaus's record of 18 majors and is remaining positive. The former world number one has not won a major since claiming the US Open title in 2008

cards.title: Football / Paderborn's Ndjeng scores 40-yard volley against Bolton
cards.rawTitle: Paderborn's Ndjeng scores 40-yard volley against Bolton

item.title: Paderborn's Marcel Ndjeng scores remarkable volley against Bolton
item.trailText: Paderborn's Marcel Ndjeng scores a staggering long-range volley against Bolton Wanderers during a pre-season friendly
item.standFirst:
Paderborn's Marcel Ndjeng scores a staggering long-range volley against Bolton Wanderers during a pre-season friendly on Monday. The midfielder fires home from the centre circle and the goal leads the crowd, including the Paderborn bench, to erupt in cheers. The German side eventually won the game 4-1

Watch the full video

cards.title: Tennis / Djokovic eyes US Open after his victory at this year's Wimbledon
cards.rawTitle: Djokovic eyes US Open after his victory at this year's Wimbledon

item.title: Novak Djokovic eyeing US Open after Wimbledon victory
item.trailText: Novak Djokovic says he is at the peak of his game and is looking forward to competing at the US Open after winning Wimbledon for the third time
item.standFirst: Novak Djokovic says he is at the peak of his game and is looking forward to competing at the US Open after winning Wimbledon for the third time. The world number one defeated Roger Federer in the final and says he hopes he can play as long as the Swiss. Djokovic has only won once at Flushing Meadows

cards.title: Football / Everton excited to show off young talent, says Martínez
cards.rawTitle: Everton excited to show off young talent, says Martínez

item.title: Everton excited to show off young talent, says Roberto Martínez
item.trailText: Everton manager Roberto Martínez says his club has the most exciting group of young players in the Premier League
item.standFirst: Everton manager Roberto Martínez says his club has the most exciting group of young players in the Premier League. Speaking ahead of his side's pre-season game against Stoke City in Singapore, Martínez says Everton are not worried about transfer windows and are instead focused on developing their young talent
